text:
I've been in the field of AI governance,
I think pretty much from the start.

It is still rapidly evolving,
 it's not settled.

How are we going to govern
this new technology?

How do we understand it,
to maximize the benefits
and also to minimize the risks?
I'll put this very directly.

I mean, the phrase AI governance
is actually ambiguous

and I think we need
to make a decision.

Are we going to govern AI
or are we going to be governed by AI?
[MUSIC PLAYING]
My name is Marc Rotenberg.

I'm Director and Founder of the Center for
AI and Digital Policy in Washington, DC.

We are a global network of AI policy
experts and human rights advocates.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

AI is today having an enormous impact on
business and society around the world.

It's transformative technology, much like
the internet or the personal computer.

It's giving individuals and businesses
and organizations new tools.

They're very powerful.
They're very impressive.
Occasionally, they make mistakes.

And to me, one of the most
interesting challenges is,

how are we going to govern
this new technology?

How do we understand it, to maximize the
benefits and also to minimize the risks?
[MUSIC PLAYING]

What AI governance is about is thinking
how we allocate those responsibilities

for safety and those rights
to promote accountability
in this rapidly evolving field?

We're learning, for example, that large
language models have great energy demands.

So now AI and sustainability
becomes an issue.

We're learning that large language
models can also produce, you know,
fantastic articles and music and artwork,

but of course,
that implicates copyright issues.

So now we need to think about
AI and its impact on copyright.
And even issues of gender equity;
when we look at the AI employment

and we look at the training
data that fuels AI models,

we ask questions about who is being
represented and who's participating.

So from the early days,
when it was largely about

decision making in the automated realm,
today we look at far more issues

that still come under the
banner of AI governance.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

I think AI and employment
is one of the very big issues
facing American businesses today

and a lot of this comes down to
how we make decisions about people.

There was a company a few years ago,
I won't mention their name,

but they believed that they could assess
whether someone was a good candidate

for a job largely by their facial
expressions or their hand gestures.

And they said, you know, you can
conduct an online interview over Zoom,

you don't even need to bring
the person into your business

or necessarily even read their resume
and we'll be able to tell you with

some degree of accuracy whether or not
they're a good fit for your company.

And you know, a lot of companies
were very intrigued by this,

because they were overwhelmed
by the number of applicants.

And this seemed scientific, which,
you know sometimes is also a giveaway

that maybe something is
being hyped or oversold.

But of course, when you started to look
carefully, you realized that things like

facial expressions and hand gestures
are often times varied by, you know,
culture and age and habit,

and don't necessarily reveal
any truth about a person.

This is the type of activity
where I do think some regulation,
you know, is appropriate.

So we need to find ways to promote
transparency and accountability

as we become more dependent on
AI-based systems for decision making.

If we don't have this ability to
understand the basis of a decision,
we're literally flying blind.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

So one of the great challenges
we face as a nation today,

is ensuring that the public policies
we develop for artificial intelligence
do reflect important American values.

Obviously, progress and
innovation are important,

but we are a country that
believes in freedom, privacy,
civil liberties, civil rights.

And to ensure that these values
are carried over into the AI era,

actually requires purposeful
actions by government,
because it's not at all clear that

companies left alone will
prioritize those values,

or even the ones that choose to
prioritize them will necessarily succeed.

So we're looking both to
the administration through

the use of the President's
executive authorities,

to the Congress
through legislation,

and even to the federal agencies
through the regulations that they issue,

to see that these
values become embedded

in the provision of AI services
and the design of AI products.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

The leader in the field of digital
regulation is often the European Union.

Many people may be
familiar with the EU GDPR,

that's the famous Data
Protection Regulation.

If you're participating
in the European market

and collecting personal
data on Europeans,

it really doesn't matter
whether you're based in Europe

or you're based outside Europe,
you're likely complying with the GDPR.

The Artificial Intelligence Act of the EU,
which was adopted earlier this year,

is likely to play a
similar role to the GDPR.

And I will say, to the credit of the
Europeans in the development of the AI Act,

they spent almost five years
seeking comments from the public,
seeking comments from business,

seeking comments from technical
experts in the member states.

The proposal went through
a number of drafts,

there was participation by
the European Parliament,

and finally, a famous process known
in EU circles as the trilogue,

which is the dialogue that occurs between the
three EU institutions to finalize the act.

So we have today in the EU the most
comprehensive AI regulation in the world,

but it does represent a
great deal of participation
by a lot of people over several years.

And I think that's a good,
you know, good process
that should generally be encouraged.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

We're talking at a
particular moment in time

about the AI legislation in
the United States Congress,

and of course,
things will change over time.

But I will say,
having been in Washington for many years

and having testified before
many congressional committees,

I'm really struck in this
moment by the high degree of
bipartisan cooperation on AI policy.

And you see this
particularly in the Senate.

One of the ways we try to measure
whether there's cooperation between

the political parties is in the
co-sponsorship of proposed legislation.

Because if it's only one
party or only the other party
that's sponsoring the legislation,

that's usually a giveaway that
there's not really consensus.

But in the AI realm, if the topic is
for example misinformation in elections,

or using generative AI to capture
the value that would otherwise
be provided by an artist or musician,

or to provide government
investment in research,

or to protect children against
images that should not be online,

all of these bills have high
levels of bipartisan support
and bipartisan co-sponsors.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

There's always, you know,
political rhetoric in politics,

and it would not surprise me at all
if President Trump will make a point

of saying that he's going to do the
opposite of whatever President Biden does.

I mean, that does seem to be a
big part of his operating style.

But in practice, at least in this field,
I will be surprised if they, for example,

try to remove regulations that
ensure safety with the AI systems

that are being deployed by federal
agencies. That's simply good government.

And it doesn't matter whether
you're Democrat or Republican,

you want federal agencies to put in
place those accountability mechanisms.

And for those who are really
interested in that field,

it's worth noting that it was
President Trump before President Biden,

who first proposed that the Office
of Management and Budget put in place

the regulations precisely
for the purpose of AI safety.

So I think it will be important that people
don't get too caught up in the rhetoric.

The rhetoric will be there, but we need
to see what the actual actions are.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

We followed Elon Musk for a
number of years in this field.

He was one of the first
people to call attention

to concerns about the
commercialization of Open AI.

When Musk put money in, he actually
believed in having a non-commercial way

to counterbalance the forces
of the established tech firms,
and he thought that was important.

And when Open AI headed off in a
different direction, he was clearly upset.

It's interesting also that Elon Musk backed
the California legislation on AI safety

that was eventually
vetoed by Governor Newsom.

So to simply assume that he is
going to be anti regulation,

I think at least based on this
history, is not accurate.
But of course, it's difficult to tell.

Most of the people who know it well,
the leading experts in AI technology,

are the ones that are calling
most loudly for regulation,

which you know, if you're familiar with the
tech field, is actually a bit surprising.

Silicon Valley, for the most part, 
has had a libertarian ethos,

not a big fan of what
happens in Washington, DC.

But at least with regard to AI, a lot of
people who know a lot about this technology

are coming to Washington
and saying to lawmakers,
“We really do need you to do something.”
[MUSIC PLAYING]

What Biden chose to do was to bring
in the tech CEOs of the White House,

get some voluntary commitments,
the companies agreeing

that they would take certain measures
to deal with some of the safety issues

and the rights issues, knowing that
legislation would be difficult to achieve.

Now, of course, there were others,
including me and my organization,
that would have preferred legislation.

You know, we don't see voluntary
commitments as a sufficient safeguard.

And at the same time, we would say that
this is a step in the right direction,

and provides the basis for legislation
that could eventually follow.

And there is some of this clearly already
taking place, where you see, for example,

the safety standards that are being
established through the safety institutes,

reflecting the voluntary
commitments that the tech companies

had previously agreed to.
So this is a form of progress.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

We're seeing what happens when there's
competitive pressure brought to bear

on firms where there are large investments,
you know, sky high expectations.

It's, I think, not reasonable or
rational to imagine that these firms
are going to be able to govern themselves.

And at the end of the day,
this is the reason why governance
is ultimately an external function.

You need legislation,
you need independent oversight.

They need to treat the companies in the
marketplace fairly and transparently.

But you know, the decision
of these companies, you know,

to fire their safety teams for example,
or to ignore the risks of misinformation,

is a warning about where we are,
but also a reminder about why it is that

we actually need legislation as these
technologies move forward so quickly.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

You know, there's a view that
says, you know,

the Europeans are all about regulation
and the US is all about innovation

and you really don't see
much regulation in the US.

But I think if you
actually look more closely,

there's a very different
story that's emerging.

Because of course, it's not only in
Washington where you have lawmakers

co-sponsoring bills on a
wide range of AI topics.
You go down to the state level

and you see Colorado passes
a comprehensive AI law,

California, I think, enacted more than
a dozen AI laws in the past session,

Texas is looking at an AI law that
remarkably looks very much like the AI law
of the European Union.

And if that seems surprising to
you, actually it shouldn't be,

because if we take a step back for a
moment, when we try to answer the question,

we have a new technology, it obviously
offers, you know, some great promise,

how are we going to put in
place, you know, the guardrails,

so that the risks are minimized
and the benefits are maximized,

and we can measure where
we're making progress

and identifying where we're
running into problems?

The guardrails look pretty
much the same, right,

for the roads in Texas and the
roads in the European Union,
because the goal is basically the same.

And I'm anticipating that over time,
we'll likely see increasing convergence
in these regulatory approaches,

because the problems that are
being faced are very similar.

It really doesn't matter
where in the world you are.

We've seen this in the
data protection realm;

privacy laws around the world
all have similar attributes.

But at the same time, you also see
innovative regulatory responses
as new challenges emerge.

The European AI Act was
moving toward the finish line,

when suddenly foundational
models were dropped into the mix,

and so the writers of that legislation had
to make some pretty significant changes
so that by the time the law was adopted,

it fairly reflected the state
of technology at the time.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

So, this discussion about new technology
and regulation is actually more complex
than most people are aware.

And one of the reasons it's more complex,
 almost paradoxical,

is that the United States is well known
for one of the most sweeping regulations

in the technology world, which was Section
230 of the Communications Decency Act.

And what that regulation,
technically law, essentially did

was to provide a very broad immunity
to any internet-based publisher

that was making available
the content of others.
We call these companies today platforms.

And Section 230 said to these platforms,
you know, whatever is being published,

it could be child pornography,
it could be defamatory,

it could be whatever your category is
of things you'd like not to see online,
you will not be legally responsible.

Whoever initiated the publication
will be legally responsible.

Well, the problem with Section
230 as a practical matter

is that it did push the
liability to the endpoints.

Meanwhile, the companies in
the middle that were offering

links to books and to news
stories and new forms of media,

were able to capture the
revenue generated by the traffic

of internet visitors
going to their websites,

which became very profitable
for a small number of firms.

I mean, these are the big
companies we talk about today,

notably Google and Facebook that, you
know, captured that advertising revenue

that had gone in the past to news
organizations, in part because 230 had

immunized them from the consequences
that the publishers still faced.

I don't think the US Congress is going
to repeat 230 for AI-based services.

The issue will come up,
for example again in copyright,

I don't think there'll be a 230
to protect these companies today
because of this prior experience.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

In the spring of 2023, our center,
the Center for AI and Digital Policy,

filed a detailed complaint with
the Federal Trade Commission,

which is a consumer protection
agency in Washington,

and we asked the FTC to
open an investigation
of the Open AI product, ChatGPT.

This is a product that can be used
to defeat cybersecurity mechanisms,

to promote misinformation, to undermine
democracy, to threaten children's safety.

All of those terms and
conclusions, by the way,

are taken from the
company's own documents.

And we were actually happy to
read over the summer of 2023,

both the New York Times and the
Wall Street Journal reported that
the FTC had opened the investigation.

But here we are a year later,
and the FTC has still not acted.

They've issued some very good business
guidance on AI services, which we favor,

but they haven't acted on
our original complaint.

And we recently prepared a report
for the US Congress titled,

No Time For Delay: Open AI
Guardrails and the FTC.
And our point is simply this,

the longer the FTC waits to
establish the necessary safeguards,

the more difficult we anticipate
the task is going to be.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

Well, at the moment, one of the
great opportunities for AI governance
is the adoption of this new treaty,

which came out of an extensive
negotiation at the Council of Europe.

Now in this domain,
the Council's mission is human rights,
democracy, and the rule of law.

And so not surprisingly, the treaty,
which was finalized this year,

has the aim of advancing democracy,
human rights, and the rule of law
for AI around the world.

Once again,
the United States led this effort.

It was supported by the member states of
the European Union and many other states.

We're optimistic about this AI treaty.
We spent quite a bit of time working on it.

We think it would be very beneficial
for the United States and its allies

to have a common agreement,
a baseline to protect these basic values.

We fully anticipate that countries
will do additional legislation.

It's not the final step in
the process of AI governance,
but it is a very important foundation

and it's actually very important that
it happen sooner rather than later.

So we have launched, through the
Center for AI and Digital Policy,

a global campaign in support of
the Council of Europe AI treaty

and we are urging countries all around
the world to support this bold initiative.

We think this is, you know,
an idea that is critical
to the human management of AI.

I'll put this very directly. I mean, the
phrase AI governance is actually ambiguous.
And I think we need to make a decision.

Are we going to govern AI,
or are we going to be governed by AI?
And if we want to govern AI,

that means that we need to
take the necessary steps

to put in place the legal
framework that ensures that

AI remains human-centric
and under our control.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

My advice to business
leaders in this moment

is to make sure that you
stay on top of these systems,

you understand these systems,
and you can manage these systems.

Now, that may not sound
particularly insightful
but here is the challenge with AI.

You see, increasingly the systems are black
boxes, opaque, aren't easily understood

even by the designers and the engineers,
but the outcomes are very impressive.

And there's a seductive process that's
underway when we see these outputs,

whether it happens to be very good
marketing text or increase in ad revenue,

and we don't fully understand it,
and we don't ask too many questions;

that is not a good place
for a leader to be.

You need to understand
what is producing results,

and you need to anticipate, you know,
what could be great failures on systems.

I'm very much concerned these
days about the increasing use
of AI systems in the physical world,

the management of devices,
autonomous vehicles, autonomous weapons.

And if you follow what the AI experts
are telling us about this moment,
first they say it's dangerous,

and secondly, they say, once we cross
this line we may not be able to go back.

I don't see companies solving
that problem on their own,
particularly in competitive markets

where the interest is necessarily
going to be to push forward.

And that's why we do need
effective AI governance.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
